name: snooker
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
[ U ] a game played, especially in the UK, by two people in which cues (= long, thin poles) and a cue ball are used to hit 15 red balls and six balls of different colours into six holes around a table covered in soft cloth in a fixed order Compare
pool noun (GAME)
cougarsan/iStock/Getty Images Plus/GettyImages
[ C ] in the game of snooker or pool, a position from which a player cannot make a direct legal shot at any ball: Stevens conceded after failing to escape from a series of snookers. need snookers
(in the game of snooker) to need to put your opponent in a position from which they cannot make a direct hit at any ball, in order to have a chance of winning a frame (= part of a match): He potted a long yellow ball to leave Davis needing snookers.
UK (of a player or sports team) to be in a situation in which it is almost impossible for them to win: United were left needing snookers. Without him England would still need snookers to save the first Test.

snooker verb [T]
(BALL GAME)
in the game of snooker, to hit the balls into a position from which your opponent cannot make a direct legal shot at any ball : O'Sullivan was snookered in the 13th frame.

snooker verb [T]
(CAUSE PROBLEM)
UK informal to prevent someone from finishing an intended plan of action: We had intended to go driving around Scotland, but unless I can get my licence we're snookered. He accused Washington of snookering developments that could have helped his brother.
US informal to deceive or trick someone: Critics say it is the administration's way of snookering students into paying for more fast-food restaurants.
